did.abstract: The Barnum Museum building has gone through various incarnations since it was first opened in 1893. In the 1950s and 1960s, the museum collections were managed by Elizabeth Seeley (a Barnum descendent). Her organizational files represent a window into the museum's inner workings during that time period, just as it was turning into a recognizable version of the contemporary Barnum Museum.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: The building that now houses the Barnum Museum originally was constructed for the sake of the Bridgeport Scientific Society, Bridgeport Medical Society, and the Fairfield County Historical Society. It was completed in 1893, having been constructed by the firm of Longstaff and Hurd. (Longstaff and Hurd also constructed P.T. Barnum's last home Marina.) Both organizations existed before the building was built, with the Fairfield County Historical Society being founded in 1881 and the Bridgeport Scientific Society being founded in the year 1878. The Scientific and Historical societies, along with the Bridgeport Medical Society, made use of the building until 1933. Membership dues and subscriptions were not enough to pay for upkeep and the societies ceded ownership of the building and their collections to the City of Bridgeport. During the 1950s and 1960s, the museum element of these organizations was revived. Acting as curator, Elizabeth Seeley directed the museum and managed its collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The contents of this collection are primarily research files maintained by Seeley. They have not been altered from the inventory conducted on the collection 1993. It is unknown if this is the original order.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material has been arranged alphabetically. Due to small size, there have been no additional series added.
